thread.section_title: Baseball - Sports News for Dallas, Texas
thread.title: From DFW to MLB: 8 locals playing in the postseason, including former Highland Park, Plano East, Allen stars
thread.title_full: From DFW to MLB: 8 locals playing in the postseason, including former Highland Park, Plano East, Allen stars | Dallas Morning News

author: Gerry Fraley
title: From DFW to MLB: 8 locals playing in the postseason, including former Highland Park, Plano East, Allen stars
text:
A look at players from local high schools on clubs in the MLB playoffs:
RHP Jake Arrieta, Plano East, Chicago Cubs Arrieta dominated the National League in the second half, going 12-1 with a 0.75 ERA in 15 starts. In a strange twist, the loss came against Philadelphia, the league's worst club. For the season, Arrieta led the NL in wins with 22 and ranked second in ERA at 1.77 and innings at 2.29. The Cubs were 25-8 in his starts.
LHP Sam Freeman, Hebron, Rangers Freeman opened the season with Triple-A Round Rock. A month working with pitching coach Brad Holman helped Freeman harness his mid-90 mph fastball. Freeman returned to the majors in mid-May and gave the bullpen a power arm. He had 40 strikeouts in 38 1/3 innings and held opponents to a .218 average.
OF-DH Evan Gattis, Bishop Lynch, Houston In his first American League season, Gattis set career-highs for homers with 27, RBIs with 88 and extra-base hits with 58. Gattis also had 11 triples, a hard-to-believe number for a player whose speed is below average. Gattis had one triple in 213 career games with Atlanta. Gattis had a .509 slugging percentage at Minute Maid Park and .415 on the road.
LHP Clayton Kershaw, Highland Park, Los Angeles Dodgers Kershaw led the majors in strikeouts with 301 in 232 2/3 innings. He joined Hall of Fame left-hander Randy Johnson and right-hander Curt Schilling as the only pitchers in this century with a 300-strikeout season. Johnson did it twice. Kershaw went 11-1 with a 1.22 ERA in his last 17 starts. He had 17 walks and 161 strikeouts in 125 2/3 innings in that span.
RHP Chris Martin, Arlington, New York Yankees Elbow tendinitis forced Martin onto the disabled list for most of May, and he needed time in the Triple-A International League to continue the recovery. Martin was 0-2 with one save and a 5.66 ERA in 24 relief appearances with the Yankees. He was used primarily when the Yankees trailed. The club was 9-15 when Martin pitched.
RHP Bo Schultz, Highland Park, Toronto The picture of determination. Schultz has been cut once by his college team (Northwestern,) released by Oakland and pitched for Grand Prairie in the independent American Association. Schultz was set to graduate school when Arizona called, and he reached the majors with the Diamondbacks last year. Schultz, a power pitcher, allowed only 1.07 baserunners per innings in 31 relief appearances with the Jays.
RHP Shawn Tolleson, Allen, Rangers Manager Jeff Banister started re-arranging the club on May 17. He removed the inconsistent Neftali Feliz as the closer and said there would be no roles in the bullpen. Banister tried Tolleson in save situations, and he converted his first 14 chances to earn the title of closer. Tolleson converted 35-of-37 chances for the fifth-best success rate (94.6 percent) among major-league closers.
RHP Chris Young, Highland Park, Kansas City A 12-game winner with Seattle in 2014, Young went unsigned until Kansas City added him on March 7 with a deal that included a low base salary of $675,000. Young served as a valuable swing-man, with 18 starts and 16 relief appearances. He was 8-6 with a 3.18 ERA for 99 innings as a starter and 3-0 with a 2.59 ERA for 24 1/3 innings in relief. The Royals were 12-6 in his starts.
RANGERS RETURN TO THE POSTSEASON Â
The Rangers are back in the postseason as the AL West Champs.
The Texas Rangers will play the No. 2 seed -- the Toronto Blue Jays Â -- in the playoffs.
